aws::graph::propositions: # Piper PA-46-350P Runway Excursion and Landing Gear Collapse Incident
Piper PA-46-350P airplane with registration N224JJ departed the left side of the runway at Sugar Land Regional Airport.
The incident occurred on December 15, 2014, at approximately 1030 central standard time.
The airplane was registered to Dilkara Leasing LLC.
Dilkara Leasing LLC was based in Las Vegas, Nevada.
The flight was operated under the provisions of 14 Code of Federal Regulations Part 91.
The flight was classified as a personal flight.
Visual meteorological conditions prevailed at the time of the accident.
An instrument flight plan was filed for the flight.
The airplane departed from Georgetown Municipal Airport in Georgetown, Texas.
The departure from Georgetown Municipal Airport occurred at approximately 0940.
The commercial rated pilot was not injured in the incident.
The pilot reported crossing the runway threshold at 100 feet altitude.
The pilot reported crossing the runway threshold at 85 knots airspeed.
The pilot touched down on the runway at approximately 80-85 knots.
When the nosewheel touched the runway, the airplane veered sharply left.
The pilot applied right rudder to correct the leftward movement.
The airplane continued off the left side of the runway despite the pilot's corrective actions.
The nose gear collapsed during the runway excursion.
The airplane came to rest approximately 150 feet from the runway.
An operations supervisor from the Fixed Based Operator inspected the marks left on the runway after the accident.
The runway marks indicated the nosewheel turned 90 degrees to the left upon initial contact with the runway.
The accident caused damage to the airplane's propeller.
The accident caused damage to the airplane's nose landing gear.
The accident caused damage to the airplane's lower cowling.
The accident caused substantial damage to the airplane's firewall.
A Federal Aviation Administration Inspector examined the engine compartment after the incident.
The inspection revealed the engine mount had broken at the nose landing gear actuator attach point.
Piper Aircraft, Inc. issued Service Bulletin 1103 on April 22, 2002.
Service Bulletin 1103 addressed engine mount inspections of Piper Malibu and Mirage aircraft.
The Service Bulletin requires Piper Malibu operators to inspect engine mounts for cracks at the next scheduled maintenance event.
The Service Bulletin requires subsequent engine mount inspections every 100 hours of time in service.
The Service Bulletin requires engine mount inspections at each annual inspection.

text:
# Factual Information

## History of Flight

| Prior to flight | Aircraft inspection event |
| Landing-landing roll | Runway excursion |
| Landing-landing roll | Landing gear collapse (Defining event) |
| Landing-landing roll | Nose over/nose down |

On December 15, 2014, about 1030 central standard time, a Piper PA-46-350P airplane, N224JJ, departed the left side of the runway at the Sugar Land Regional Airport (SGR), Houston, Texas. The commercial rated pilot was not injured. The airplane was registered to operated by Dilkara Leasing LLC, Las Vegas, Nevada under the provisions of 14 Code of Federal Regulations Part 91 as a personal flight. Visual meteorological conditions prevailed at the time of the accident and an instrument flight plan was filed. The airplane departed the Georgetown Municipal Airport (KGTU) Georgetown, Texas, about 0940.

The pilot reported that he crossed the runway threshold at 100 feet and 85 knots, and touched down on the runway about 80-85 knots. When the nosewheel touched the runway, the airplane veered sharply left. He applied right rudder; however, the airplane continued off the left side of the runway. The nose gear collapsed and the airplane came to rest about 150 feet from the runway.

The pilot stated that after the accident, an operations supervisor from the Fixed Based Operator (FBO) inspected the marks left on the runway. The pilot added that at the point where the nosewheel first contacted the runway, it appeared the wheel turned 90 degrees to the left.

Examination of the airplane revealed damage to the propeller, nose landing gear, lower cowling, and substantial damage to the firewall. An inspection of the engine compartment by the responding Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Inspector, revealed the engine mount had broken at the nose landing gear actuator attach point.

Piper Aircraft, Inc., issued Service Bulletin 1103 on April 22, 2002, which addressed engine mount inspections of Piper Malibu and Mirage aircraft. The Service Bulletin requires Piper Malibu operators to inspect the engine mounts for cracks at the next scheduled maintenance event, and each 100 hours' time in service, or annual inspection thereafter.
